choices.answer: Using sound waves to "paint a picture" of what's around you.
a GPS navigation system
The ability for animals' eyes to see really well at night.
A tracking device placed on animals to follow them around.
Sounds too low-pitched for humans to hear
Sounds too high-pitched for humans to hear
Sounds too loud for humans to hear
Sounds too soft for humans to hear
A form of ultrasound used by animals to catch prey
A form of ultrasound used as a medical instrument by doctors
A form of ultrasound used by submarines and ships underwater
None of the above

questions.question: How do bats and other animals use echolocation to see?

choices.answer: They make high pitch sounds that zap their prey
They make low pitch sounds that draw their prey to them
Make high pitch sounds that bounce off prey and back to them
None of the above

questions.question: Which of the following animals uses echolocation to hunt? (More than one possible answer)

choices.answer: Owls
Toothed marine mammals (dolphins, some whales)
Humans
Bats

questions.question: In what ways do humans use ultrasound/echolocation/sonar?

choices.answer: Medical examinations of babies in the womb
Locating fish and shipwrecks, and mapping the seafloor
Blind individuals painting a picture of their surroundings
All of the above

questions.question: True or False: Bats are blind.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: Bonus: How do bats know which direction their prey is moving?

choices.answer: They use their 20/20 vision to watch their prey move
They have no idea where their prey is going
They know left and right by which ear the sound enters
For distance, high pitch = coming closer, low = moving away
